sentences.sentence: the data obtaie by the sim (sim) and the solar stellar irradiance comparison experiet instruments onboard the solar radiation and climate experiet (sorce) satellie reveal that the uv variability during down branch of the 23rd solar cycle (2004-2009) can be several tie higher in comparison with other ssi data and that the signs of the solar irradiance trends due to the 11 year activity are different in the visible and uv regions
moreover, the solar irradiance variability measured by the sim (sim) and the solar stellar irradiance comparison experiet (solstice) is different in their common part of the spectrum (210-290 nm)

in this paper, we study the atmospheric response to solar irradiance variability using four different ssi data sets (sim, solstice-based composie lean et al reconstruction, and constant solar forcing)
sim: composiewhich contains the sorce solstice data from 121 to 210 nm and the sim data from 210 to 750 nm
solstice: composiewhich contains the sorce solstice data from 121 to 290 nm and the sim data from 290 to 750 nm

we analyze the data for the period from may 2004 to february 2009 as the shortwave (210-310 nm) sim data are only available for this period of tie we used the solstice data up to 290 nm and the sim data from 210 nm according to the recommendations of the sorce team
two of the used data sets are based on measurements of the solar irradiance by the sim and solstice instruments onboard the sorce satellie which was launched on 25 january 2003

the solstice instrument, which is a follow-up to the solstice onboard upper atmospheric research satellie(uars) launched in 1991 , measures the daily spectral irradiance with absolute accuracy of 5% and with relatieaccuracy of 0% per year in the spectral range from 115 to 320 nm

the sim instrument is a newly designed spectrometer that measures the irradiance in the visible and near-infrared from 300 to 1600 nm with an additional uv channel (200-300 nm) that overlaps with the solstice irradiance measurements
in this paper, we used the reported sim irradiance in the visible range
the absolute accuracy of the sim instrument at visible waveleghs is about 2%

to provieredundancy and selfcalibration capability, sim contains two completely independent and ietical (mirror-image) spectrometers; the relatieaccuracy is based on detaie comparisons of these two spectrometers during the april 2004 to november 2007 (3 years) tieframe and are valid through the tieperiod consieed in this paper and are consistent with the values quoted in harder et al

a detaie description of the sim instrument was published by harder et al , and the measurement equations for the degradation corrections are presented in the auxiliary materials section in harder et al
below 400 nm, the contrast is calculated by employing uars/solstice observations, whieabove 400 nm, they are based on the model by solanki and unruh

in the 200-350 nm range, the variability measured by solstice and sim is significantly stronger than the variability yielded by the nrl model

mls (mls) instrument onboard the aura satellie aura was launched on 15 july 2004 on a sun synchronous near-polar orbit
mls observes the thermal emission from the earth's limb in spectral intervals with centers at 118 ghz, 190 ghz, 240 ghz, 640 ghz, and 2 thz

sbuv measures the uv irradiance scattered by the earth's atmosphere

discussion and summary eos mls long-lie tracegs observations have led to the discovery of a previously unreported phenomenon

although the claes (claes) on the upper atmosphere research satellieobserved long-lie tracers during parts of spring 1992 and 1993, pv fields in those years do not indicate conditions favorable for a friac to form, and there is no indication of a friac signature in claes data

whiethere may be some eviece of such features in previous sparser data sets (such as those from high-latitude solar occultation instruments), the nature of the friac - the lack of a persistent signature in o3 or pv, small gegaphic extent, and rapid motion - is such that it is unliey that this phenomenon could have been reliably ietified without global or hemispheric daily profiemeasurements of longlie tracegses such as those from eos mls

2 sage ii and sage iii sage instruments provieh2o, o3, and aerosol profie from measurements of solar radiation attenuated through the earth's limb during sunriesunset events viewed from the satellie' orbits
sage ii was launched in october 1984 aboard the earth radiation budget satellie(erbs) and made measurements spanning 80 s-80 n until august 2005
sage ii was a seven-channel photometer measuring in the range from 0 to 1 m (mccormick, 1987), with h2o (o3) retrieved from the channel at 0 m (0 m)
sage iii was launched into a sunsynchronous orbit (100 inclination) on 10 december 2001, aboard the russian meteor 3m platform
sage iii operated until november 2005, measuring in 87 channels ranging from 0 to 1 m
here, we use version 7 data from sage ii (damadeo et al 2013), which is an update from the prior version (version 6; thomason et al 2004)
version 7 includes updated o3 spectroscopy to be consistent with the most recent sage iii processing and a new determination of the h2o channel filter parameters
we exclude sage ii h2o data before 1 january 1986 due to a known drift in the h2o channel filter parameters during this tieperiod (thomason et al 2004)
for sage iii, we use version 4 data (thomason et al 2010)
the sage ii data are retrieved on a 0 km grid from the surface to 50 km for wv and 0 to 70 km for o3
for sage iii both wv and o3 are retrieved on a 0 km grid from 0 to 100 km
the sage iii h2o resolution is 1 km (thomason et al 2010), and the o3 resolution is 1 km (hassler et al 2014)

sage ii h2o data are filtered according to the published recommendations of taha et al (2004) and rind et al (2005) to remove poor-quality retrievals and profie impacted by high volcanic aerosol loading (eg following the eruption of mt
for sage ii o3, we filter data based on the recommendations of wang et al (2002, based on v6 data), with the additional crieia set forth in the sage ii version 7 release notes
as with the sage ii h2o, this filtering removes aerosol contaminated and poor-quality retrievals
for sage iii data, the data were prescreened by the retrieval team, so with one exception no additional screening is necessary
the only screening applied to sage iii data is removal of a few weeks worth of bad data during 2002, following the recommendations of thomason et al (2010)
we also apply a 3 filtering, as with the sage ii data
2 the upper atmospheric research satellie(uars) was launched into a near circular (57 ) orbit in september 1991 and operated until november 2005
the uars mls instrument measured emitted microwave radiation from the earth's limb using three heterodyne radiometers centered at 63, 183, and 205 ghz (barath et al 1993)
latitudinal coverage of uars mls was either 34 s-80 n or 34 n-80 s, depending on the spacecraft yaw position which switched every 36 days

we use the uars mls version 6 data (pumphrey, 1999; pumphrey et al 2000), which is retrieved at six levels per decade of pressure (resulting in 2 km vertical resolution) and produces useable profie between about 100 and 0 hpa
the uars mls vertical resolution is approximately 3-4 km throughout most of the stratosphere (pumphrey, 1999)

o3 was retrieved separately from both the 183 and 205 ghz channels, but we use only the 205 ghz version 5 o3; it is the recommended product for stratospheric o3, and it extends through the end of the uars mission, unliethe 183 ghz product (lieey et al 2003)

2 in addition to uars mls, the halogen occultation experiet (haloe) operated on board uars from october 1991 until november 2005, making solar occultation measurements in the infrared (2-10 m) with latitudinal coverage from 80 s to 80 n (russell iii et al 1993)
haloe contains six broadband channels for simultaneous retrieval of h2o (6 m) and o3 profie (9 m) from approximately 10 to 90 km
haloe data are retrieved on a 0 km grid from 1000 hpa to 1 10 6 hpa (271 levels), although in general data are usable only above 100 hpa
the haloe vertical resolution is 2 km for h2o and o3 (harries et al 1996; kley et al 2000)

here, we use the haloe version 19 (v19) products, which have been extensiey compared with independent satellie balloon, and ground-based measurements (kley et al 2000; hegin et al 2013; nedoluha et al 2007)
the haloe o3 and h2o data are filtered by first removing any trip angle or constant lockdown angle events ietified by the data provies (http://haloegts-inc
haloe nochannel extinction for tropical data (30 s-30 n) at a number of different pressure levels
all profie screened by this new algorithm occurred before november 1992 in the first year of operation of haloe, when volcanic aerosols from the mt
2 the aura mls instrument was launched in july 2004 aboard nasa's eos aura satellie(waters et al 2006)

the aura mls instrument measures thermally emitted microwave radiation from the earth's limb using fieradiometer channels spanning 118 ghz to 2 thz; o3 is retrieved from the 240 ghz channel (froieaux et al 2008; jiang et al 2007; lieey et al 2008), and h2o is retrieved from the 190 ghz channel (lambert et al 2007; read et al 2007)
the aura mls obtains 3500 profie per day and achieves nearly global coverage between 82 s and 82 n

the data filtering for the aura mls data is similar to that for version 2 data discussed in lambert et al (2007) for h2o and froieaux et al (2008) for o3, but with updated values presented in the aura mls version 4 data quality document ()
additional filtering that has been applied to the aura mls wv data to remove low-biased data in the utls is descrie in appendix a
this filtering is motivated by the dry bias present in the mls data, as descrie in the next section
this appendix descrie a new algorithm for screening out aura mls wv profie in the utls that are dry biased and contain unphysical oscillations

the motivation for appendix a is that rather than simply remove all mls data below a predetermie pressure level, it is desirable to retain as much of the aura mls data in the utls region (eg at lower latitudes) that are thought to be unaffected by the dry bias
the screening procedure descrie in appendix a has been applied to all aura mls wv data stored in swoosh, so no action on the part of swoosh users is requie

3, haloe data are extremely dry biased (values < 50 % of the fp data) below 147 hpa
this extreme dry bias occurs because haloe retrieval saturates under tropospheric conditions when the wv values are above 10 ppmv

this is reflected in the haloe/fp comparison at 147 hpa (not shown): haloe data show mean dry biases 50 % when fp values aregeater than 8 ppmv, as opposed to a 10 % dry bias for values less than 8 ppmv
to avoid a (dry) biased monthly mean from haloe, we exclude haloe data at and below the 147 hpa level

the crieia chosen for these stations are that all stations use the electrochemical concentration cell (ecc)type o3sondes and proviea data record that extends back to the start of the sage ii record in 1984

briefly, the homogenization process involves adjusting data from the individual satellieinstruments such that their mean values agree with the reference satellie(ie sage ii for o3 and aura mls for wv)

the matching between the reference and non-reference data set for each species is possible for all combinations of data sets except between aura mls and uars mls for h2o, since their records do not overlap
in the absence of instrument overlap for these two instruments, we use the (adjusted) haloe wv as a transfer standard
after matching, we interpolate all satelliedata onto the swoosh vertical grid, which corresponds to the aura mls vertical grid containing 12 levels per decade in pressure from 316 to 1 hpa
this grid is coarser than the retrieval vertical grids of all of the other instruments except for uars mls, which has roughly half the number of vertical levels as aura mls

we conducted tests smoothing the higher-resolution data down to the 3 km resolution of aura mls and did not find large changes in the computed offsets, even near the tropopause, indicating that the offsets are caused more by fundamental retrieval issues than simple differences in vertical resolution of the measurements

recent advances in horizontal sampling by instruments on the aqua and aura satellie not only reduce this uncertainty, but in some cases are now providing a fully resolved three-diesional view of gravity waves from space

for example, the high horizontal resolution airs (airs) observations, with a 13-km nadir footprint and imaging capability, have deep vertical wegting functions that limit the detection of waves to those with vertical waveleghs longer than 12 km
the high resolution dynamics limb sounder (hirdls) on the nasa eos-aura satellieoffers the highest vertical resolution to date from an infrared limb profiling instrument in space
the longitudinal sampling is much higher near the turn-around latitudes of the hirdls measurement track which are near 80 n and 64 s
gravity waves are clearly observed in hirdls data via vertical t fluctuations in the retrieved t profie
we present here a similar analysis of hirdls data, exploiting hirdls' higher vertical resolution and horizontal sampling
these results highlight the high resolution afforded by the hirdls data and their value for quantifying the most urgently needed properties of gravity waves on a global scale

maps of gravity wave properties derie from hirdls averaged over 30 d in may 2006 and averaged over the hegt range 20 - 30 km
the patterns are very similar to previous results from lims and crista
both of these were limb-viewing infrared instruments, and the analysis techniques included a wierange of vertical waveleghs, although hirdls can observe shorter vertical waveleghs

the hirdls t amplitude map also has some features similar to maps of gravity wave potential eneg derie from short vertical scale variance in t profie derie from gps occulation measurements and radiosondes

they also show seasonal asymmetry at higher latitudes, with larger values in winter, although the increase with latitude in winter is much weaker than in hirdls where long vertical waveleghs that were excluded in the previous studies occur
this lower value may be due in part to the poorer vertical resolution of hirdls compared to gps

for better comparison to the gps and sonde results, we computed simple hirdls t variance without the removal of zonal wave numbers 1 - 3 (not shown), and peak amplitudes derie from this variance near the equator were then 2 k
these combie effects bring the hirdls t amplitudes into very close agreement with previous measurements of short vertical wavelegh waves in the tropics

t variance maps derie from the upper atmosphere research satelliemls (uars-mls) included only long vertical wavelegh waves >12 km , and these maps show the large increase at high latitudes in the winter hemisphere but do not show a peak at the equator
average t amplitudes derie from the uars-mls data are very small 0 k and liey explaie by the combie effects of wegting function attenuation and intermittency on the average

vertical wavelegh from crista displayed no obvious global trends , whereas the hirdls results show a distinct trend with increasing vertical wavelegh from the equator to high latitudes in the southern (winter) hemisphere
ern et al analyzed data from august 1997, whieour hirdls results are for may 2006
the crista and hirdls analyses used different maximum wavelegh cutoffs, 30 and 16 km, respectiey, which might explain some differences
the differences in the vertical wavelegh latitudinal trends between crista and hirdls might also simply be due to the higher vertical resolution of hirdls compared to crista
the improved vertical resolution of the hirdls data may mean they simply include more of the short vertical scale waves known to exist in the equatorial region
hirdls, with its high vertical resolution that extends over a deep region of the atmosphere, can clearly observe both types of waves
the waves ietified in our hirdls analysis do not show the flattened distribution that indicated severe undersampling in crista at high latitudes
although undersampling is liey for some of the waves in the hirdls maps, it does not appear to be a pervasieissue
quantitatiedifferences between crista and hirdls may have numerous origins

for vertical wavelegh and horizontal wave number, the differing resolution of the two data sets will tend to allow hirdls to see a larger portion of the wave spectrum than crista, and we expect to see a decrease in the minimum vertical wavelegh and increase in the maximum kh, as observed

this difference could tend to decrease the number of wave events we observe, but the high resolution and longer duration of the hirdls mission leave an abundance of wave events to study even with our stricter crieion

discussion and summary we descriea global analysis of hirdls highresolution t profiedata to derieproperties of gravity waves
the vertical wavelegh distributions in hirdls show substantial variations titude not previously seen in other data sets

the reason for the new result is liey associated with the high vertical resolution of hirdls and the deep region of observation up to 60-km altitude, both of which allow the determination of a wie range of vertical waveleghs not possible in previous analyses
we should further note that hirdls sensitivity to the shortest vertical waveleghs in this range remains to be determie
undersampling of short horizontal wavelegh waves in the hirdls data is another issue that could result in systematic biases in horizontal wave number and momentum flux with latitude

for example, if high horizontal wave number gravity waves have a preference for zonal propagation dietions, then the hirdls sampling would favor their characterization at the high-latitude limits of the measurements and would result in gross underestimates of horizontal wave number and momentum flux at low latitudes
the hirdls data set represents a very valuable information source on thegobal properties of gravity waves that we have only begun to exploit

2 the merra dataset in this study, the merra reanalysis dataset was chosen because it extends to 0 hpa, this includes the stratosphere and much of the mesosphere
the merra reanalysis uses the goddard earth observing system data assimilation system version 5 (geos-5) model (rienecker et al 2011)
geos-5 uses two gw parametrizations: drag from orographic gws based on mcfarlane (1980), and drag from non-orographic gws based on garcia and boville (1994)

the consistency of the additional levels with the interpolated levels of the final merra product has been found to begod by comparing tieseries and the climatologies of overlapping levels around 0 hpa

the merra data represent well the polar stratospheric circulation (rienecker et al 2011) and capture most features of the upper stratosphere-lower mesosphere as well as the tieevolution of the undisturbed polar stratopause
despiethese limits, manney et al (2008) conclude that analysis systems using the geos-5 model are appropriate to study the pw structure near the stratopause
this is why the main features of the ssws in the merra data shown in this study are believed to be quiewell representatieof the real circulation
to validate the merra representation of the stratopause, the satelliemls high-resolution data and the high resolution dynamic limb sounder (hirdls) data have been used
mls is positioned at a 705 km sun-synchronous orbit and measures thermal microwave emissions from the earth's limb up to a latitude of 80 (waters 2006)
hirdls has a better vertical resolution than mls (1 km), a latitude coverage up to a latitude of 80 and the t precision at the stratopause is 1 k (gille et al 2003)

in order to ietify the stratopause in merra, mls and hirdls data, we use the algorithm developed in france and harvey (2013), detaie as follows: the t data is interpolated from pressure surfaces to geometric hegt an 11 km box car vertical smoothing of the t is applied to smooth the local small extrema at each point on the horizontal grid

3 comparisons with satelliedata in this section the representation of the stratopause during sudden stratospheric warmings is assessed in the merra dataset by comparison with satellieobservations
figure 4 shows the daily northern polar cap t (averaged over 70-88n) from the merra (bottom), mls (middle) and hirdls (top) datasets for the period 2004-2012

however, when the middle atmosphere is affected by strong ssw events eg in 2005/2006, 2008/2009, 2009/2010 and 2011/2012, the stratopause drop just after the onset date is under-estimated in the merra dataset
in particular, the es formation after the strong 2006 vortex displacement and the strong 2009 vortex splitting is not represented in the merra data as observed in manney et al (2008)
figure 5 explores these issues further by showing the difference between polar cap t for the merra and mls data for 30 day periods either sieof the 5 ssw events shown in the previous ifgure
there is an underestimation of the downward propagation of the upper stratospheric warming in the merra data set, where the disturbed mid-stratosphere is colder by 15 k before the ssw than mls
in the mesosphere the merra analysis is too warm, underestimating the 1 3 mesospheric cooling (by about 20 k) in the merra data before the ssws

both these differences, and the subsequent underestimation of the stratopause descent are probably due to an imperfect parametrization of gws in the middle atmosphere in geos-5, the model used for the data assimilations for the merra dataset
gie that the geos-5 model has an upper limit at 0 hpa (75 km), it can clearly not reproduce a stratopause above this

moreover, the es events have been associated with non-orographic gw drag (wright et al 2010; chandran et al 2011; limpasuvan et al 2012; tomikawa et al 2012; yamashita et al 2013) so poor parametrization of gws in geos-5 at high altitudes could be another reason for the absence of es events and for the errors in the middle atmosphere representation after the warmings in merra data (manney et al 2008)
nevertheless, even if the merra dataset cannot fully reproduce the extreme stratopause behaviour, it can help to understand several of its features during ssw events

the early o3 comparisons indicate overall agreement at roughly the 5 - 10% level with stratospheric profie from sage ii, haloe, poam iii, and ace

mls o3 values tend to be slightly higher than the occultation data sets in the lower stratosphere, and slightly low in the upper stratosphere, but the degree of ''tilt'' in this slope of the average differences changes from one comparison to the next, indicating that there are also differences between the occultation data sets themselves (see froieaux et al for more details)

over most of the recommended vertical range, the estimated single-profieprecision reported by the level 2 software varies from 1 to 1 ppbv; the observed scatter in the data, evaluated in a 20 -wielatitude band centered around the equator where atmospheric variability is expected to be small, suggests a measurement precision of 1 ppbv throughout the profie preliminary comparisons with a climatology based on seven years of uars mls hno3 measurements suggest that eos mls hno3 may be biased high by several ppbv near the profiepeak
much closer agreement with the uars climatology is generally found at other latitudes/altitudes/seasons

comparisons of hno3 profie from mls and ace at middle and high latitudes in both hemispheres over the january - march 2005 tieperiod indicate that, in an average sense, mls hno3 is high relatieto ace by at least 2 - 3 ppbv (30%) at the levels surrounding the profiepeak

average agreement between the two satelliemeasurements is better (typically within 10%) near the top and bottom of the profie despiethe apparent offset between mls and ace near the profiepeak, however, comparisons of nearly coinciet individual measurements show good agreement in capturing the overall shapes of the hno3 profie and tracking variations in them

sumner, nm in september 2004 lead to similar conclusions: mls mixing ratios exceed those measured by the balloon instruments by as much as 3 ppbv at the levels around the profiepeak, with agreement typically much better at the top and bottom of the vertical range

the discrepancies between hno3 abundances measured by mls and those measured by ace, firs-2, and mark iv may ariein part because of uncertainties in either the infrared or the microwave spectroscopy; this possibility is under investigation

the altitude, latitude, and seasonal dependence of the apparent high bias in the mls version 1 hno3 data will be explored in more detail in future validation studies, both through analysis of potential shortcomings in the mls retrieval system and comparisons with additional correlatie(ground-based, aircraft, balloon, and satellie data sources
comparisons of mls and haloe hcl for january - march 2005 indicate that mls hcl abundances are typically high, relatieto haloe, by 0 to 0 ppbv (10 to 15%)

we analysed the homogeneity of various observational records of the stratospheric o3 vertical distribution at ohp by comparing lidar measurements with ecc o3sondes and umkehr measurements at ohp and with sbuv(/2), sage ii, haloe, uars mls, aura mls and gomos satellieobservations, extracted above the station
sbuv(/2) observations display a shift around 2001 at 15-10 hpa and to a lesser extent at 6-4 and 4-2 hpa
sage ii and haloe provierelatiey less sampling at ohp in spring and summer
the best agreement with the lidar data is found for sage ii with an rms difference of 2 % in the 15-45 km range, as compared to the other long-term data sets
shorter observational records such as uars mls, aura mls and gomos were also analysed to check their measurement consistency
uars mls displays positiebiases and are relatiey larger compared to aura mls
aura mls shows good agreement with the lidar at 20-40 km, but negatiedeviations above 40 km, with gomos also showing such a tendency during some seasons
aura mls yields very small and non-significant drifts (0-0 % yr1) at 15-42 km with the lidar, comparable to those of the long-term data sets

the average trend obtaie was 0 ppmv/yr with haloe measurements, whereas it was 0 ppmv/yr with wvms measurements

it observes thermal microwave emission from earth's limb viewing forward along the aura spacecraft flight dietion, scanning its view from thegound to ~90 km every ~25 s

as earth rotates underneath it, the aura orbit stays fie relatieto the sun to giedaily global coverage with ~13 orbits per day

operational nwp systems, by their nature, must assimilate data that are available in near-real tie for o3, these datasets include total-o3 observations from the toms (toms) and the global o3 monitoring experiet (gome), partial o3 columns from the solar buv radiometer (sbuv), and satellieradiance measurements from o3-sensitiechannels such as the high-resolution infrared sounder (hirs) channel 9

for example, struthers et al (2002) assimilate data from the upper atmospheric research satellie(uars) mls (mls), and geer et al (2006a) descriea series of assimilation experiets that use data from the michelson interferometer for passieatmospheric sounding (mipas)
in this paper, we assimilate o3 data from the earth observing system (eos) mls (mls)
this instrument is mounted on the eos aura satellie which was launched on 15 july 2004
the aura satellieflies in a polar orbit, and orbits the earth about 14 tie per day
the aim of this study is to use the met offiedata-assimilation system to ietify the improvements to o3 analyses that result from adding eos mls o3 data to the assimilation system

the results are potentially of great interest to operational nwp centres, for two reasons: if a clear positieimpact to o3 analyses from eos mls data is shown, then there may be more chance of realizing the above-listed positieimpacts of o3 analyses on other assimilated fields (for example, via the o3/radiation interaction); although the eos mls data aregnerally not available in near-real tie any benefits from assimilating these data could very well also accrue from assimilating data from the next generation of satellieinstruments, such as gome ii and the infrared atmospheric sounding interferometer (iasi), which fly on the recently-launched metop satellieand which will be available in near-real tieto operational centres
the eos mls o3 data are descrie in section 2, together with other observational data that are used to evaluate the observational analyses
assimilated data in the data-assimilation experiets descrie in this paper, o3 data from both eos mls and sbuv instruments are assimilated
eos mls the eos mls o3 profie assimilated here are version 1 (for the january - february 2005 and january 2006 experiets) and version 1 (for the june 2006 experiet)
eos mls is on the nasa aura satellie which flies in a near-polar sunsynchronous orbit
there are around 14 orbits per day; on each orbit eos mls observations span a region from 82 s to 82n; retrievals are made every 165 km along the suborbital track (waters et al 2006)

comparison with other satelliedata shows that in the stratosphere agreement is generally within 5% - 10% with data from the halogen occultation experiet (haloe), the stratospheric aerosol and gas experiet (sage ii), the polar o3 and aerosol measurement (poam iii) and the atmospheric chemistry explorer (ace)
at 215 hpa, limie comparison with southern-hemisphere additional o3sondes (shadoz) indicates that eos mls has a positiebias (sometie up to 100%) in the tropics
sbuv sbuv/2 is a nadir-viewing instrument that infers the o3 vertical profieby measuring sunlight scattered from the atmosphere in the middle ultraviolet
in section 4, the assimilation results are evaluated by comparison with independent data from o3sondes, haloe and toms
version 19 haloe retrievals are used here
haloe data are available for the period from 11 october 1991 to 21 november 2005
toms toms measures back-scattered ultraviolet radiances with high horizontal resolution (38 km by 38 km) and daily near-global coverage
this has partial corrections for calibration problems in the post-2000 toms data from the earth probe satellie and improved retrievals under extreme conditions compared with version 7

a full validation of toms version 8 has not yet been published, but version-7 uncertainties have been estimated as about 2% for the random errors, 3% for the absolute errors, and somewhat more at high latitudes because of the higher zenith angle (mcpeters et al 1998)
here, eos mls o3 profie and sbuv o3 densities are assimilated, together with all operational dynamical observations, using a stratosphere - troposphere version of the met offieassimilation system
the assimilation code for the eos mls profie is based on that used to assimilate retrieved profie from mipas
the observation error is taken dietly from the precision estimate supplied by the eos mls science team, and no bias correction related to the biases reported above is carried out

the sbuv data are subjected to a quality-control procedure prior to use in the assimilation system, and observations with a solar zenith anglegeater than 84 or with a quality flag greater than 0 are blacklisted

in the first trial (ctrl), background o3 is calculated by the forecast model but no o3 data are assimilated; in the second (sbuv), o3 data from sbuv are assimilated; and in the third (mls), sbuv and eos mls o3 data are assimilated
in section 4, an initial comparison of the three runs is made via inspection of analysed zonal-mean o3 fields and of o3 analysis errors with respect to o3sonde, haloe and eos mls data
then a more detaie investigation is made of regions where there are particularly striking differences between the assimilations made with and without eos mls data
the three-way comparison of the runs ctrl, sbuv and mls is restricted to one month because of the computational expense involved in running these trials
however, mls has been run for two other periods: january 2006 and june 2006
the differences between runs ctrl and sbuv show that o3 is reduced in the lower stratosphere when sbuv is assimilated
this may indicate that the o3 values in the initial conditions are too high and that the sbuv data are doing a reasonable job of correcting this bias
this is confirmed by figures 2 and 3, which show analysis errors compared to o3sondes and haloe, respectiey
mean errors for sbuv are similar to or smaller than those for ctrl in most parts of the lower stratosphere
exceptions are in the northern hemisphere near 100 hpa (for both o3sondes and haloe) and in the tropics between around 30 hpa and 10 hpa (for haloe only)
figures 2 and 3 show that the standard deviations of the errors for sbuv are similar to or slightly smaller than those for ctrl
this shows the marginal positiebenefit to the analyses from assimilation of sbuv data
figure 1 shows that analysed o3 amounts in the mid- and high-latitude stratosphere drop even further when eos mls data are assimilated
figures 2 and 3 show that at levels up to around 35 km (or 5 hpa) the overestimation of o3 at southern latitudes is consieably smaller in mls than in the other two runs
the standard deviation of the errors is clearly smaller when compared to haloe, and smaller at many levels when compared to o3sondes

zonal-mean o3 averaged over the period 1-25 february 2005: (a) run ctrl; (b) run sbuv; (c) run mls; (d) difference between runs sbuv and ctrl; (e) difference between runs mls and ctrl; (f) difference between runs mls and sbuv
moving on to the northern hemisphere, figure 1 shows that zonal-mean o3 values at northern polar latitudes are lower for sbuv and mls than for ctrl
this could be attributed to o3 loss by heterogeneous chemistry, which is not represented in ctrl but is included, via the information from the sbuv and eos mls observations, in the other two runs
figures 2 and 3 indicate that this loss is best represented in mls, since the error standard deviation for this run is smaller than for the other two runs throughout the stratosphere
the mean error for mls is also smallest in large parts of the stratosphere: below the 30 hpa level when compared to o3sondes and between 30 hpa and 5 hpa when compared to haloe
the difference in these results below the 30 hpa level is partly explaie by the different spatial sampling of the haloe and o3sonde data used to calculate the mean errors
there are no haloe data available north of 60n during the analysis period, but several o3sonde ascents are available at these locations

thus, the impact of large differences between mls and the other runs at these latitudes (see figure 1) will be captured by the errors calculated with respect to o3sondes, but not with respect to haloe
figure 1 shows that at lower levels the vertical gradient of o3 across the tropopause is stronger in mls than in ctrl and sbuv

error standard deviations and mean error (compared to o3sondes) in the utls are smallest for mls, again indicating that the addition of mls data improves the quality of the assimilation in the northern mid-latitude utls
figure 1 also shows that the vertical gradient of o3 near the tropopause is much stronger in mls than in ctrl and sbuv
the latter two runs may have a weak gradient due to a combination of poor transport in the background field (geer et al 2006a, section 5) and the low resolution of the sbuv data at these levels
it appears that the higher-resolution eos mls data, on the other hand, can resolve the o3-field structure better

figure 2 shows that in the tropics the o3 in ctrl and sbuv is consieably overestimated, particularly near the tropical tropopause (around 100 hpa) where the analysed o3 is more than 70% greater than the o3sonde values, whereas this error is reduced by over 50% when eos mls data are also assimilated
in addition, the error standard deviation for mls is reduced by up to 40% compared with the other two runs

in this paper we have demonstrated the benefits of adding eos mls o3 profie to the met offieo3 data-assimilation system

when eos mls observations are included, mean analysis errors, and the analysis error standard deviation, are found to be consieably smaller than in other runs where only sbuv o3 data are assimilated (sbuv), or where no o3 data are assimilated (ctrl)

compared with the latter runs, mean errors for mls drop by 5% - 25% in the southern-hemisphere extratropical stratosphere, by around 10% in the northern-hemisphere extratropical stratosphere, and by around 50% (with respect to o3sondes) in the tropical utls
such reductions in errors indicate the high quality of the eos mls dataset
the experiets have been run using version 1 or version 1 eos mls retrievals
these loes are present in mls for both january - february 2005 and january 2006 (latter results not shown)
both mls and ctrl reproduce this structure well, but the depth of the loe is underestimated in ctrl
in contrast to mls and ctrl, sbuv fails even to adequately represent the structure of the loes
it appears that the low vertical resolution of the sbuv data assimilated leads to a smearing of any realistic o3 structure present in the background field

this is a difficult problem to overcome in data assimilation, but it appears that the high horizontal and vertical resolution of the eos mls data, and their low biases, mean that this problem can be circumvented
in the northern hemisphere, the addition of eos mls data to the assimilation system leads to a better representation of winter polar o3 depletion
comparison of analysed and o3sonde profie at various locations indicates that mls in particular does well in representing the strong gradient of o3 near the vortex eg
in the tropical utls, the assimilation of eos mls data leads to a better representation of the strong vertical gradient in o3 between the upper troposphere and the lower stratosphere
the o3 analysis in this region can be adversely affected by model transport errors, and indeed the horizontal structure of o3 fields here in ctrl and sbuv appears to be too noisy
the addition of high-density, good-quality eos mls data alleviates much of this error
furthermore, the mls o3 analysis errors in the tropical utls are consieably smaller than errors from similar experiets made using mipas data (geer et al 2006a)
this may be because there is less vertical noiein the eos mls o3 profie
the mipas data aregnerally consieed to be a high-quality, very useful, dataset, so this result underlie how good the eos mls o3 retrievals are
another point not consieed is that the mipas experiets of (geer et al 2006a) were run for the period july - november 2003, whereas we focus on eos mls results for january - february 2005
therefore, it is possible that interannual and seasonal variability may account for the differences in the eos mls and mipas results
however, we show in section 4 that most of the mls errors are similar whether the assimilation is run for january - february 2005, january 2006 or june 2006
of course, a more complete assessment of the impact of eos mls data on our o3 analyses would requieassimilations to be run for other seasons and longer periods

2 2 mopitt the mopitt (measurements of pollution in the troposphere) instrument is a nadir infrared correlation radiometer onboard the nasa terra satellie(drummond and mand, 1996)

2 mls the mls (mls) (waters et al 2006) onboard the aura spacecraft was launched on 15 july 2004 and placed into a near-polar earth orbit at 705 km with an inclination of 98 and an ascending mode at 13:45 h
mls observes thermal microwave emission from earth's limb in fiespectral regions from 118 ghz to 2 thz
the mls co measurements are made in the 240 ghz region
the mls co level 2 products used in this paper are produced by version 2 of the data processing algorithms

the vertical resolution of mls co retrieved profie is about 3-4 km in the stratosphere and the horizontal resolution is between 500 km for lower stratospheric levels and 300 km for upper stratospheric levels

the mls co data set was validated by lieey et al (2008) for the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere and by pumphrey et al (2007) for the stratosphere and the mesosphere where the accuracy was estimated to be 30 ppbv for pressures of 147 hpa and less

a priori information for the retrieval of hno3 profie were obtaie from the nasa/jpl mls (mls) experiet aboard of the eos aura satelliefrom 2004 to date (waters et al 2006; santee et al 2007)

for testa grigia, where the gbms was operated for 4 winter periods, from 2004 to 2007, and thule, where observations were carried out during polar winters 2008/2009, 2009/2010, and 2010/2011 concurrent mls data are available

we averaged together all the mls hno3 vertical profie obtaie during the gbms observation periods within 2 latitude and 10 longitude from each observing sie a smoothing was then applied in order to remove fievertical structures in the mls mean profie
for gbms measurements obtaie at the south pole in 1993 and 1995, the first generation of mls was operating, aboard the upper atmosphere research satellie(uars)

however, the use of uars/mls measurements as a priori for gbms south pole retrievals would have two major drawbacks: (1) uars/mls has a limie coverage of the extreme polar regions, reaching a southernmost latitude of only about 80 and switching monthly between viewing northern and southern high latitudes; (2) uars/mls hno3 measurements are less reliable than aura mls data, especially in polar winters, with potential biases as large as 45 ppbv insiethe vortex (lieey et al 2003)

in light of the above points and consieing that we are interested in an a priori profiecontaining information on the mean hno3 distribution in a certain region rather than on the hno3 profiefor a specific date or year, the a priori profiefor the south pole gbms measurements was built using aura mls measurements south of 80 s during the first two years of mls operations (2005 and 2006)
mean mls profie obtaie with this procedure provieadequate information on the typical behavior of the hno3 throughout the year at the south pole
data from the 2006 and 2007 observing campaigns at testa grigia were not used in this study for consistency with the mls validation paper of santee et al (2007) based on 2005 gbms hno3 profie
as mentioned above, gbms hno3 measurements discussed here had been previously compared to satellieobservations obtaie from the nasa/jpl mls experiets onboard of uars and eos aura satellie

according to this comparison, gbms hno3 measurements carried out at testa grigia in 2005 were biased toward higher mixing ratios with respect to aura mls v2 hno3 profie by as much as 3 ppbv (20-30 %) near the peak (santee et al 2007)
et al (2007), however, also reported a low bias of mls v2 hno3 profie of 1 ppbv at the mixing ratio peak with respect to other satelliedatasets
a similar high bias (2-3 ppbv) was observed in the gbms hno3 1993 polar fall measurements with respect to the uars mls v5 hno3 data, in the range 20-27 km (muscarie al 2002)

during winter, in the same altitude range, with a denitrified lower stratosphere, the same comparison displayed gbms values lower than mls mixing ratios by 1-2 ppbv, and this difference was ascrie in muscarie al (2002) to non lierities in the mls retrieval system ts

according to the differences observed between gbms hno3 v1 and v2 retrievals, it appears that v2 profie are in better agreement with mls data sets with respect to that shown by v1 profie in previous comparisons
preliminary studies (fioruccie al 2009) comparing gbms v2 and aura/mls v3 hno3 vertical profie at testa grigia support this result

version 2 profie bring no improvement in the antarctic winter case, where, however, lower stratospheric differences between gbms and mls measurements are liey due to the uars mls v5 retrieval system (muscarie al 2002)
a comprehensieintercomparison between gbms v2 and aura/mls v3 hno3 vertical profie is underway

consieing the results of muscarie al (2002) and santee et al (2007), this difference suggests that gbms hno3 v2 profie have a better agreement with both uars/ and eos aura/mls hno3 data than previous gbms hno3 v1
an intercomparison study between gbms v2 and aura/mls v3 hno3 vertical profie at mid- and high northern latitudes is being undertaken

introduction in 2007, mcpeters et al introduced an o3 climatology designed to be used in satellieretrieval algorithms for backscattered ultraviolet (buv) measurements
we use buv to designate thegneral technique, whiea specific instrument such as sbuv is capitalie
this climatology, sometie designated the llm climatology, was used in the version 8 retrieval of o3 profie from nasa sbuv and noaa sbuv/2 instruments

the 2007 climatology was consieably more detaie than the simple climatology that had been used for previous versions of the sbuv and toms retrievals , which consisted of only 26 profie with o3 in umkehr layers ( 5 km) covering low, mid, and high latitude zones
a low vertical resolution version of this same climatology with total o3 dependence added was used for total column o3 retrievals from toms and omi

the sbuv team is now egged in reprocessing data from the entieseries of sbuv instruments, from the original nimbus 4 buv instrument launched in 1970 through the sbuv/2 instruments on noaa 16, 17, and 18 which are currently operating
new o3 cross sections, those of brion et al and malie et al were used, and a new cloud hegt climatology based on omi retrievals was used

we have updated the mcpeters et al climatology by using o3 profiedata from the aura mls instrument, taking advantage of the excellent latitude coverage of mls and its improved accuracy at low altitudes over the uars mls instrument

the sbuv profieretrieval algorithm derie a very accurate measure of the total amount of o3 between thegound and about 25 km, but has little information on how it is distributed

data for the climatology o3 retrievals using the backscattered ultraviolet (buv) technique benefit from an o3 climatology that has coverage from the surface to approximately 60 km, vertical resolution good enough to resolve the rapid o3 change in the upper troposphere / lower stratosphere, good latitudinal coverage, and seasonal tiedependence
data from the mls instrument on the aura spacecraft come close to meeting all these crieia
because the mls retrieval loses accuracy below the 215 hpa level , sonde data are used to produce the climatology in the troposphere
the revie climatology is very similar to the mcpeters et al climatology but uses aura mls data rather than the sage ii data used previously

since aura is in a sun synchronous orbit with a 1:30 local equator crossing tie the aura mls has nearly complete latitude coverage daily and its measurements are always near noon or near midnight (except at high latitudes)
we use daytiedata only for the new climatology as most appropriate for our solar buv retrievals
the mls instrument on aura relies mostly on the 240 ghz band for its o3 retrievals
this band gie much better accuracy in the troposphere than the uars mls instrument
comparisons with sondes show that mls version 2 has very good accuracy down to at least the 215 hpa level
the vertical resolution of mls is 2 to 3 km, from the upper troposphere to the midmesosphere
because of thegod performance of mls in the lower mesosphere, we now extend the climatology up to 65 km
mls version 3 data from late 2004 through 2010 were averaged to create the climatology
based on comparisons with mls they argue that this asymmetry is mostly in tropospheric o3

aura is in a sun-synchronous near-polar orbit (98 inclination) with a 1345 lt ascending equatorial crossing tie the day and night are therefore equally covered each 24-h period

the ongoing analysis of a 10-y hourly nexrad dataset for may through august of 2004-2013 confirms the diurnal, annual, and gegaphical patterns found by solomon et al (51)

subsequent to the high in situ h2o observations reported by anderson et al (2), schwartz et al (57) analyzed satellieobservations of h2o from mls and confirmed that the lower stratosphere over the unie states in summer is, indeed, unusually wet, with measured values reaching as high as 18 ppmv
the mls satelliedata indicate that the highest stratospheric h2o mixing ratios at the highest latitudes globally are over the central and eastern unie states in summer

these results are particularly noteworthy, because the true magnitude and number of h2o enhancements over the unie states in summer is liey significantly greater than reported by the mls satellieinstrument

this discrepancy occurs because elevated h2o from convectieinjection is localie in space and typically layered vertically, such that the spatial resolution of mls (eg 3 km vertical 200 km horizontal at 100 hpa for h2o) may often exceed the diesions of the perturbation or randomly transect it, leading to an underestimate of the mixing ratio

for example, a 2-km-deep layer of elevated water of 50-km horizontal extent, even with optimal alignment of the convected geometry along the northsouth viewing track of mls, will only fill 1/6 of the mls sample volume, with the other 5/6 filled with background levels of h2o; this results in a substantial underreporting of the actual h2o mixing ratio present within the convected domain

another key piece of eviece relating the observations of enhanced h2o to their convectiesource comes from the atmospheric chemistry experiet-ace-fts (ace-fts) satellieobservations of the concentration of the heavy water isotopologue hdo globally in the lower stratosphere (58) as well as in situ observations of hdo within regions of convectieinjection from nasa aircraft missions (1)

mls was launched onboard the aura satelliein july 2004
mls consists of seven radiometers covering spectral regions from 118 ghz to 2 thz
mls provie about 3500 profie per 24 h period covering both day and night
mls daytieand night-tieprofie are determie by averaging profie with local solar tie between 10-14 and 22-2 (next day), respectiey
the vertical resolution of mls data ranges from 3 km in the lower stratosphere to about 5 km in the lower mesosphere, with a useful vertical range between 100 and 0 hpa ( 16-70 km)
mls has retrieval errors of about 5 % in the middle and upper stratosphere and 10 % in the lower stratosphere (froieaux et al 2008)
an upper atmosphere research satelliesolar ultraviolet sim (uars/susim)-based correction is applied to waveleghs below 270 nm to gain better agreement with observations (krivova et al 2006)
to calculate irradiance below 400 nm, a regression with uars/solstice (solar stellar irradiance comparison experiet) observations is performed
the sorce mission is descrie by rottman (2005)

for the sorce fluxes used here, we combiedata from two of the instruments on board sorce: the solar stellar irradiance comparison experiet (solstice; mcclintock et al 2005); and the sim (sim; harder et al 2009, 2010)
it is based on solstice (version 10) below 200 nm and on sim intermediate-release version (j
we label this data set sorce_1
the use of sim data below 310 nm is no longer recommended, so we also included two test runs using the currently available sorce data
these data are labelled sorce_2 and use solstice (version 12) and sim (version 17) data for waveleghs below and above 310 nm, respectiey
due to limie tiespan of the sorce data tieseries, a multi-annual simulation could not be performed with these fluxes
run d_sorce2004_1 and e_sorce2007_1 are therefore two separate 10 yr simulations with constant sorce_1 solar fluxes for december 2004 and december 2007, respectiey
two additional simulations with recently updated sorce_2 solar fluxes are included as run f_sorce2004_2 and g_sorce2007_2
as shown in haigh et al (2010), at 210 nm sorce data show nearly 6 % more uv in december 2004 (solar maximum period) than in december 2007 (solar minimum period)

a robust positiesolar signal in the middle stratosphere is clearly visible in the model simulations as well as saber and mls data sets
for example, the secondary solar signal maxima in the tropical lower stratospheric o3 observed in sbuv, sage and slimcat are not visible in saber and mls data
again, the solar signal from these simulations shows quieod agreement with the solar signal from sage and sbuv data (soukharev and hood, 2006)
the model is also able to reproduce changes over the recent 2004-2007 tieperiod, which has previously been used to support the different solar flux variability measured by sorce

therefore, our model runs do not provieany indiet support for the accuracy of the sorce fluxes; rather they argue that the previously accepted nrl-ssi or satire-s fluxes are able to reproduce recent observed o3 changes

our modelled o3 solar signal in the middle and upper stratosphere during the 2001-2010 tieperiod is different to that deduced from sbuv or sage data (1979-2003), but only slightly different (similar structure but larger in magnitude) to haloe (1992-2005)

however, there are some uncertainties in the sbuv (eg poor vertical resolution) and sage (eg limie temporal sampling, twomey-chahieinversion near 50 km) data sets (eg terao and logan, 2007; wang et al 2011)
a re-evaluation of sbuv and sage data is needed to confirm if the solar signal in stratospheric o3 during the recent solar cycle is indeed out of phase with tsi changes

the o3 climatologies in the form of monthly zonal mean tieseries covering the upper troposphere to lower mesosphere are obtaie from lims, sage i, sage ii, uars-mls, haloe, poam ii, poam iii, smr, osiris, sage iii, mipas, gomos, sciamachy, ace-fts, acemaestro, aura-mls, hirdls, and smiles within 1978-2010
a detaie comparison versus sage ii data is presented, which can help ietify suitable candidates for long-term data megng studies
the sage ii o3 data set is consieed to be the most reliable long-term satelliedata source for the detection and quantification of o3 changes in the lower stratosphere

however, sage ii covers the tieperiod between 1984 and 2005, and whiemany newer satellieinstruments have provie vertical o3 distribution since 2000, a thorough assessment of the newer measurements with each other and the older datasets is critical in order to create a megd data set that can extend o3 trend analysis beyond the lieieof the sage ii instrument

note that although the sbuv/2 (solar buv/2) instruments proviea long-term o3 record with excellent coverage and density, the data are nadir viewing only and not included here due to their limie vertical resolution
the sage i climatology include altitude corrections
the sage iii climatology does not include a separate retrieval for mesospheric o3; therefore it should be used with care
note that uars-mls data are not as good for trend studies after june 1997 as a result of sparser data and missing mls t retrievals
data sets from sage ii, uars-mls, haloe, poam ii, poam iii, smr, osiris, sage iii, mipas(1/2), gomos, sciamachy, ace-fts, ace-maestro, aura-mls, and hirdls are included in the 1996-2010 evaluations
lims and sage i data are compared separately for their overlap period in 1979

since sage ii has a very long data record and is used extensiey in validation and long-term studies, it is also of interest to use sage ii as a reference for comparisons with other satelliemeasurements
these additional comparisons are derie for the maximum overlap tieperiod for each individual instrument with the sage ii mission
due to their limie latitudinal coverage, poam ii/iii and sage iii are not included in the evaluation of the annual mean cross sections
the climatologies from sage ii, uars-mls, osiris, gomos, aura-mls and hirdls yield a very good agreement with differences to the mim of up to 5% and often even below 2%
slightly larger differences are found for haloe, mipas(1/2), and ace-maestro reaching values of up to 5% and in some regions up to 10%

smr, sciamachy, and ace-fts show a good agreement with the other instruments with positiedifferences of up to +10% (+20% in the us) for the latter two and negatiedifferences of up to -10% in the case of smr
in the ls, differences are larger compared to the regions above, however in the mid-latitudes and tropics sage ii, mipas (1/2) and aura-mls agree well with differences only occasionally exceeding 10%
exceptions are uars-mls, haloe, osiris, gomos, and hirdls, which show consieable local disagreement of up to 50%
uars-mls o3 values below 100 hpa have a known high bias and their use is not recommended
whiethese pressure levels have not been included in the uars-mls climatology, the levels dietly above 100 hpa can be affected through interpolation of the high-biased values
sage ii and osiris in the ls show very good agreement with the mim in nh high latitudes but display large deviations at sh high latitudes

ace-fts and ace-maestro, which also suffer from non-uniform sampling, show differences with respect to the mim that are very similar in structure, but opposieto that of osiris, aura-mls and gomos consistent with a validation study by dupuy et al

at high latitudes, differences with respect to the mim are larger (locally up to 50%) when compared to the tropics and midlatitudes, in particular for osiris in the sh, sage ii, haloe, gomos, sciamachy, ace-fts, and ace-maestro

however, the large differences at high latitudes observed for some instruments (eg sage ii, haloe, osiris (sh), and gomos in 2003) are also present in the monthly mean comparisons and are not exclusiey introduced by the annual averaging
a comparison of the lims and sage i climatologies for february to april 1979 is shown in figure 3 (left panels)
for all the three months included in the evaluation lims has mostly negatiedeviations when compared to sage i

note that the differences are reversed in may when lims has a mostly positiedeviations from sage i (figures a1 - a1 in the sparc data initiatiereport), very liey related to sage i sampling issues, with sunriemeasurements only early in the month in the northern hemisphere (nh) and sunset measurements only in the sh

the evaluation of the smiles climatology is based on a comparison of its zonal mean o3 cross-sections (averaged from january to april 2010) to the mim of all instruments available for the same tieperiod (ace-fts, ace-maestro, aura-mls, gomos, mipas(2), osiris, sciamachy, smr, and smiles)

all instruments agree within 5% except for ace-fts, which has deviations of up to -10% below 10 hpa, and sciamachy, which has deviations of up to +20%, clearly overestimating the o3 mixing ratio peak at 10 hpa
overall, the best agreement is found between sage ii, osiris, gomos and aura-mls in the tropical and mid-latitude ms/us
in particular, hirdls, gomos, and uars-mls show large positiedeviations in the ls
sage ii has a long data record and shows in general very good agreement when compared to o3sondes
in order to extend long-term trend analysis of global o3 profie beyond the end of the sage ii data record in august 2005, information from more recent satellieinstruments is needed

in order to determiewhich instruments show the best agreement with sage ii in each region, and could therefore be a suitable choiefor data megng activities, a comparison of each instrument to sage ii is performed here

the comparisons are done for the maximum overlap tieperiod of each individual instrument with sage ii, ie each comparison is based on a different tieperiod varying from 15 years (for the comparison with haloe) to 6 months (for the comparison with hirdls)
figure 5 displays the comparison of sage ii to 15 instrumental climatologies
deviations between sage ii and the individual instruments vary with latitude and altitude, and no instrument can be singled out as giving the best agreement with sage ii everywhere

in the tropical and midlatitude ms gomos and aura-mls show excellent agreement with differences below 2%, whieuars-mls, haloe, osiris, sage iii, and mipas(1) have only slightly larger deviations to sage ii, often up to 5%
the largest departure from sage ii can be found for ace-maestro, ace-fts, sciamachy and mipas(2) with differences up to 20% in some places
for the tropics and midlatitude us, the comparisons show similar results as the ms, with excellent agreement of osiris and gomos to sage ii (2%)
in the tropical ls, differences to sage ii data increase with decreasing altitude for most instruments
aura-mls, osiris, as well as mipas(1/2) display the best agreement
in the tropical ut, nearly all data sets (except haloe and ace-maestro) show larger o3 values than sage ii, consistent with the known low bias for sage ii with respect to o3sondes in this region

observed vertical oscillations (mainly at low latitudes) in the aura mls panel are largely caused by systematic oscillatory features in the mls utls retrievals that are expected to be mitigated in a future data version
in the nh polar latitudes, hirdls, uars-mls, osiris, and mipas(1) agree well and poam iii agrees very well with sage ii

in the sh, aura-mls, osiris, haloe, smr, and uars-mls have only small offsets compared to sage ii of up to 10%, whieother instruments reveal larger differences of up to 20%, or even 50% in the case of gomos
overall more than half of the instruments agree very well with sage ii in the ms/us showing mean deviations of less than 5%
for example, the o3 cross-section used in the sage ii retrieval is about 2% lower compared to the one used by gomos
neglecting other potential systematic differences, we would then expect sage ii to be about 2% larger than gomos due to the different o3 crosssections, which is in fact the case in the ms
the overall best agreement to sage ii is found for aura-mls, osiris, and mipas(2) in the ls, aura-mls and gomos in the ms, and osiris and poam ii in the us
the seasonal cycle is well captured by sage ii, haloe, gomos, mipas(2) and aura-mls, which show only small differences in phase and amplitude when compared to the mim
due to their limie temporal sampling in the tropics, ace-maestro and ace-fts climatologies provieonly weak constraints for fitting a seasonal cycle
uars-mls agrees quiewell for most months but shows an outlier for may, which adversely affects the fit
uars-mls shows significantly larger o3 values compared to the other instruments , as already noted for the annual mean comparison
despiethis offset, uars-mls, sage ii, haloe and aura-mls estimate a very similar amplitude and phase for the seasonal cycle with maximum values in july or august

the instrument-by-instrument analysis reveals that whiesciamachy and hirdls have a very similar phase compared to the mim they show a much smaller or, respectiey, a much larger amplitude, with the latter possibly related to hirdls' better vertical resolution

gomos, mipas(1), osiris, mipas(2), ace-fts, and ace-maestro all show consieable differences in the phase, and additionally the first two display a too large and the latter three a too small seasonal cycle amplitude

there is a large spread in the signal displayed by the instruments, with the biggest discrepancies observed for osiris, haloe, and acemaestro with larger amplitudes for the latter two and relatiey shallow seasonal cycle for osiris
the mim includes sage ii, uars-mls, haloe, smr, osiris, mipas(1/2), gomos, sciamachy, ace-fts, ace-maestro, aura-mls, and hirdls

the objectieof the current work is to assimilate the information contaie in all ssmis channels using a state-of-the-art prototype operational nwp system extending to ;100-km altitude (ie to the ''eg of space'')

for these studies, mesospheric ts from two research satellieinstruments were assimilated: the sounding of the atmosphere using broadband emission radiometry (saber) limb sensor on the national aeronautics and space administration (nasa) thermosphere ionosphere mesosphere enegtics and dynamics (timed) satellie and the mls (mls) on board nasa's earth observing system (eos) aura satellie since timed and aura are research satellie saber and mls observations are not generally available in near-real tie although some effort has been made recently to provienearreal-tiemls data products (lambert et al 2012)
currently, ssmis is the only operational meteorological sensor with upper atmospheric sounding (uas) channels that proviemeasurements in the mesosphere (see fig
it is currently deployed on three separate dmsp satellie: f16, f17, and f18, with two additional instruments awaiting launch in the near future

in this study, we examiewhether assimilation of ssmis-uas data in a high-altitude nwp system using fast rt modeling that includes the zeeman splitting effect can provierealistic mesospheric analyses of comparable quality to those previously obtaie from assimilating mesospheric t profie from research satellie (hoppel et al 2008; eckermann et al 2009)

aura mls nasa's mls (waters et al 2006) on the eos aura polar orbie has been providing global t profie since july 2004 that span the upper troposphere to lower thermosphere
by viewing the limb from the front of the aura spacecraft, mls continuously acquie data between 828s and 828n (see fig
the aura orbit is sun synchronous and has a 1345 local equatorial crossing tie(lt) on the ascending node (0145 lt descending)
2, these equatorial crossing tie are ;4 h earlier than the closest ssmis instrument, so there are no close tiespace coincieces between mls and ssmis observations, except near the pole
mls retrieves atmospheric t using limb observations of the 118-ghz o2 and the 234-ghz o18o spectral lie
we use the version 2 (v2) mls ts descrie in schwartz et al (2008)
the newer version 3 mls ts are largely unchanged from v2 except in the troposphere (lieey et al 2011)

comparisons of mls v2 ts with correlatiedatasets (schwartz et al 2008) showed that, whiethe bias in the stratosphere was generally less than 2 k when compared to other observations, there are some persistent vertical oscillations with respect to several other measurements near the stratopause, and these oscillations have amplitudes as large as 2-3 k
in the mesosphere mls v2 ts are biased low (;0-7 k) compared with a number of other correlatiedatasets
the horizontal resolution of the mls t measurements in the middle atmosphere is ;180 km along track and ;12 km cross track

ideally, the broadening of the vertical wegting function in the mesosphere should be incorporated into the mls assimilation, using a forward model to calculate a t jacobian similar to radiance assimilation
instead, we treat mls here as a simple t profie oversampled to the model vertical resolution, an approximation that may introduce some biases to the assimilation

ssmis the ssmis instruments measure earth's radiation in 24 microwave channels using a conical scan cycle consisting of 180 measurements spanning 143 of azimuth at a constant off-nadir viewing angle of 458, producing radiance imagery with a swath width of ;1700 km
there are currently three ssmis sensors in operation on the dmsp f16, f17, and f18 satellie
the fast scanning pattern yields a greater gegaphical density of measurements than limb sensors liesaber and mls, as illustrated in fig

the primary obstacles have been (i) the altitudes to which these channels are sensitiehave exceeded the upper boundaries of many nwp systems, and (ii) the difficulty in accurately yet rapidly forward modeling radiances in ssmis channels 19-21
we will group these three channels with the ''normal'' ssmis channels for our da experiets and limit our evaluation to channels 19-21 in the remainder of this paper
radiatietransfer calculations han et al (2007, 2010) have developed a fast rt model for the ssmis uas channels that includes the zeeman effect as well as the frequency shift due to earth's rotation

to make use of the ssmis zeeman capability, the crtm requie two new input parameters for each measurement: thegomagnetic field stregh and the angle between the microwave antenna boresight and thegomagnetic field

the uas data for this work were processed and produced by the ssmis-uas unified preprocessor (upp) that has been developed at nrl and patterned after the original upp jointly developed by the met offieand nrl (bell et al 2008)
comparisons with saber here we compare the saber-derie brightness ts with ssmis uas radiances
this comparison is similar to that performed in han et al (2007), except that in addition to ssmis f16 data, here we have included data from f17 and f18

because saber profie do not reach the surface, we interpolate the nasa goddard earth observing system version 5 (geos-5) analyzed ts (rienecker et al 2008) to the tieand location of the saber measurement and then spliethe geos-5 and saber t profie together across an interface near 10 hpa
the crtm forward model is then run using this megd t profie together with the appropriate zeeman parameters (magnetic field vector and antenna pointing vector) taken from the coinciet ssmis data
despieusing only one day of data per month, the total number of coinciet profie is greater than 30 000 for each ssmis instrument
saber and ssmis measurements are consieed to be coinciet if they are made within 18 (;111 km great-circle distance) and 3 h of each other
saber profie are allowed to be coinciet with multiple ssmis soundings

performing a similar coinciet comparison with mls observations is problematic
first, as noted in section 2b, close mls-ssmis coincieces only occur near the poles
second, the mls wegting functions are vertically broad in the mesosphere (schwartz et al 2008)
the crtm assumes that the resolution of the input atmospheric profie matches that of the internal model grid, but mls ts smooth out the true t structure such as the minimum at the mesopause
also, there are unexplaie systematic differences between mls and saber polar ts that need to be understood before differences between uas-mls and uas-saber comparisons can be interpreted
tuning of thegavity wave parameterization was performed using the january 2009 tieperiod and minimizing the t differences between 5-day forecasts and mls measurements
the ssmis bias estimation includes an additional ascending/descending pass predictor
saber and mls data are not subject to an automatic bias correction scheme
however, a global pressure-dependent static t correction is applied to the mls ts
this correction is a vertically smoothed version of the mls-saber differences found in the mls validation study of schwartz et al (2008)
from 1 to 0 hpa, the estimated mls bias is positiewith a peak value of 15 k at 1 hpa

ssmis is continuously acquiring atmospheric radiances from the operational dmsp f16, f17, and f18 polar orbies, yet to date observations from its three highest peaking uas channels, spanning altitudes ;40100 km, have not been fully utilie by any operational nwp system
tasks (ii) and (iii) led to a t239l60 navgem configuration extending to ;0 hpa that allowed us to assimilate ssmis uas radiances using the crtm forward operators in our 4d-var solutions

two experiets were, in essence, controls: a ''nomesoobs'' experiet that assimilated no mesospheric observations at all, and another experiet that assimilated research-quality mesospheric ts from saber and mls

the other two experiets each assimilated uas radiances: one that also assimilated mls and saber data and another that did not, so as to assess the mesospheric impacts of assimilating operationally available uas data only
comparisons of results among the four experiets highlighted the large beneficial mesospheric impacts of assimilating ssmis uas radiances
in particular, the experiet that assimilated only uas radiances produced results very similar to those assimilating mls and saber ts

an earlier nogapsalpha 3d-var production run assimilating mesospheric mls and saber ts had yielded large-scale mesospheric ts, winds and planetary-wave dynamics that were extensiey validated in a number of previous studies (eg hoppel et al 2008; eckermann et al 2009; mccormack et al 2010; coy et al 2011)

therefore, the close correspondence between mesospheric results from the uas-only and mls1saber experiets indicates a that a reliable operational mesospheric analysis can be obtaie by assimilating all the ssmis uas channels

since ssmis uas channels provieour only source of real-tiemesospheric observations for such systems at present, it is both reassuring and encouraging that our uas-only experiets produce mesospheric analyses of comparable quality to those assimilating research-quality mesospheric t retrievals

whiethere are two additional ssmis instruments with uas channels slated for future f19 and f 20 deployments, there are currently no plans for uas channels on any other meteorological satelliesensors, raising the possibility of a future mesospheric data void, despiehaving operational nwp systems extending through the mlt

a recently published joint iwc retrieval product (dardar) combining cloudsat-calipsomodis (moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer) observations shows robust consistency with cloudsat iwc without losing the signal from thin ieclouds (delanoe et al 2010, 2013; eliasson et al 2013)

4 ut cloud tilt cloudsat, dardar observations and wrf cloudresolving simulations all suggest that systematic ut cloud mass tilts tend to occur at the northern and southern peripheries of tropical deep convectieregions

clearly, neglecting systematic cloud tilt in satellieretrieval can result in additional biases especially for limb sensors (eg mls), nadir sensors at slantwieview-angles (eg airs, modis) and conical sensors (eg clouds and the earth's radiant eneg system)

for example, gong and wu (2011, 2013) acknowlegd the impact on airs cloudies in the zonal dietion, where they concluded that up to 50 % of airs view-angle asymmetry could be attributed to the systematic westward-tilted cloud structures in the ut

randel and cobb (1994) analyzed the msu channel 4 t and toms (toms) total o3 data and found globally coherent o3 and t perturbations associated with el nino and la nina

randel et al (2009) analysed zonal mean t from the radiosonde innovation composiehomogenization (rich) dataset and zonal mean o3 from sage ii satellie and found similarlysigned variations in t and o3, which are a signature of ensoinduced fluctuations in zonal mean vertical velocity near the tropical tropopause

the aura mls fields-of-view point in the dietion of orbital motion and vertically scan the limb in the orbit plane, leading to data coverage from 82 s to 82 n latitude on every orbit

the primary instrument is the ace-fts, a ace-fts featuring high resolution (0 cm1, corresponding to a 25 cm maximum optical path difference) and broad spectral coverage in the infrared (750-4400 cm1)

gmi 2 the ctm the gmi ctm is a global 3-d composition model that combie both tropospheric and stratospheric chemical mechanisms, including 124 species, 322 chemical reactions, and 81 photolysis reactions (ziemke et al 2006; duncan et al 2007a; considieet al 2008; allen et al 2010)
the details of the gmi model are descrie in duncan et al (2007a) and strahan et al (2007)

the gmi model uses a flux-form semi-lagrangian (ffsl) advection scheme (lin and rood, 1996) and also includes parameterizations of convection, wet scavegng, dry deposition, and planetary boundary layer mixing
gmi uses modules developed at harvard uniesity to calculate rates of wet scavegng (marie al 2000; liu et al 2001) and dry deposition (jacob and wofsy, 1990)
several studies have previously evaluated the gmi ctm simulations of tropospheric o3 and co

ziemke et al (2006) compared the tropospheric o3 columns (tocs) in an earlier version of the gmi ctm, which was drie by the finievolume general circulation model (fvgcm) meteorological fields (details in sect

2), with those determie from omi (omi) and mls (mls) measurements from the nasa aura satellie the comparison showed similarities with respect to zonal and seasonal variations of toc, but the model overestimated toc over northern africa by as much as 10 du, liey due to desert dust effects, whieunderestimating toc over the western pacific warm pool by up to 10 du
chandra et al (2009) evaluated gmi toc when drie by the geos4 meteorological fields (see sect

2) with omi/mls toc and found the model overestimated toc by 5-10 du for the latitude band 30-35 n all the year and over east china in winter and spring, when stratosphere-troposphere exchange (ste) is greatest

duncan et al (2008) showed that the annual average surface o3 concentrations in the gmi/geos-4 simulation had a high bias of about 11 %, with higher biases in summer, when photochemical production is the dominant source of o3

considieet al (2008) examie the ability of gmi/fvgcm (4 5 ) to represent the observed neartropopause o3 distributions and found that annual mean o3 concentrations were biased high by 45 % at the model thermal tropopause liey due to insufficient vertical resolution near the tropopause ( 1 km) and/or too-high vertical diffusivity
for co, duncan et al (2007a) compared gmi/fvgcmsimulated tropospheric co concentrations with noaa global monitoring division (gmd) surface observations

schoeberl et al (2006) showed that gmi/fvgcm was able to reproduce the uppertroposphere/lower-stratosphere (ut/ls) co tape recorder caused by seasonal changes in biomass burning, as ietified with the mls data

data sets we driethe gmi ctm with three meteorological data sets from the free-running nasa global modeling and assimilation offie(gmao) fvgcm with sea surface t for 1995, the goddard earth observing system data assim- ilation system version 4 (geos-4 das) for 2005, and the modern-era retrospectieanalysis for research and applications (merra) for 2005
merra is a nasa atmospheric reanalysis data set from a new version of geos das version 5 (geos-5)
geos-5 is a system of models integrated using the earth system modeling framework (esmf)
compared to geos-4, geos-5 adopts an analysis system developed jointly with the national centers for environmental prediction (ncep) and a different set of physics packages for the atmospheric gcm
merra has 72 vertical levels with a lid at 0 hpa (sigma-pressure coordinate interface at 177 hpa)
to improve computational efficiency, we driethe gmi ctm with the meteorological data sets at a degraded resolution (2 latitude by 2 longitude)

both fvgcm and geos-4 use the deep-convection scheme of zhang and mcfarlane (1995) and the shallow-convection scheme of hack (1994), whereas merra uses a modified version of the relaxed arakawa-schubert (ras) scheme for convection (moorthi and suarez, 1992)
merra is characterie by the weakest shallow convection in both hemispheres
merra has the strongest tropical convection in the lower free troposphere, but its tropical convection is not as deep as in the others
shallow convection in fvgcm and geos-4 extends to higher latitudes than in merra

the omi measured o3 column includes o3 between the top of the atmosphere and the optical centroid pressure (ocp)
the ocp is the characteristic pressure of a single cloud layer retrieved by omi (joie et al 2012) and is set to match the observed rotational-raman scattering signal (stammes et al 2008)
consequently, subtracting the mls stratospheric column o3 from the omi o3 column provie the in-cloud o3, defie as the average o3 concentration between the ocp and the tropopause

briefly, geos-5 uses the relaxed arakawa-schubert scheme (moorthi & suarez, 1992) to parameterieconvection

11,949 the geosccm (oman et al 2011; pawson et al 2008) uses the global modeling initiatie(gmi) chemistry mechanism (duncan et al 2007; strahan, duncan, & hoor, 2007) to simulate o3 and other tracegses within the geos-5 atmospheric general circulation model
the gmi mechanism includes over 400 reactions to represent stratospheric and tropospheric chemistry, including the interactions between nox, hydrocarbons, and o3
aerosols are simulated by the goddard chemistry aerosol radiation and transport component of geos-5 (chin et al 2002; colarco et al 2010) and interact with the gmi chemistry
